summary: This is an FBI 302 interview summary of Alfredo Rodriguez, former house manager for Jeffrey Epstein, conducted on December 3, 2009. Rodriguez describes his possession of a black bound book and handwritten notes seized by agents, details his observations of underage girls and sexual activity at Epstein's Palm Beach home, and discusses instructions from Ghislaine Maxwell and others regarding payments and secrecy.

persons.name: Alfredo Rodriguez
persons.role: Former House Manager for Jeffrey Epstein, Interviewee
persons.context: Former house manager for Jeffrey Epstein from 2004-2005, fired in March 2005. Interviewed by FBI agents and AUSA, waived his rights, and provided information about activities at Epstein's home, possession of a black book, and observations of underage girls.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Instructed Rodriguez not to discuss what occurred at Epstein's home after he was fired and told him not to contact anyone else about it. Also instructed Rodriguez on whom to make payments to and in what amount.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Rodriguez's former employer. Rodriguez describes Epstein instructing him to withdraw funds from the bank and details sexual activity with young girls observed at Epstein's Palm Beach home.

persons.name: Leslie Lnu
persons.context: A secretary in New York for Epstein's organization whom Rodriguez contacted in 2005 regarding a letter of reference.

persons.name: Jack Goldberger
persons.context: Attorney who contacted Rodriguez concerning legal representation after Rodriguez alerted Epstein's organization about receiving a subpoena in civil litigation in early 2009. Rodriguez declined his representation.

persons.name: Jean Luc Brunel
persons.context: Would bring girls to Epstein's house and sometimes arrange for girls to be flown in via commercial and private planes.

persons.name: Valsoun Lnu
persons.role: House Manager of Paris, France Property
persons.context: House manager of Epstein's property in Paris, France. Rodriguez discussed the sexual activity with young girls he observed with this individual.

persons.name: Jerome Pierre
persons.role: Gardener at Palm Beach County Property
persons.context: Gardener at the Palm Beach county property. Rodriguez believed he was aware of the sexual activity that occurred at the house with young girls.

connections.description: Rodriguez was employed as house manager by Epstein from 2004 until he was fired in March 2005.
Rodriguez received instructions from Maxwell regarding payments to girls and was told by her not to discuss activities at Epstein's home after his termination.
Maxwell acted on Epstein's behalf, instructing staff like Rodriguez on financial payments and enforcing secrecy.
Rodriguez observed that Brunel would bring girls to Epstein's house and arrange for their travel.
Brunel supplied girls to Epstein's home, as described by Rodriguez.
Goldberger contacted Rodriguez to offer legal representation after Rodriguez received a subpoena; Rodriguez declined.

events.title: Seizure of Black Book and Notes
events.description: Agents seized a black bound book and handwritten notes from Alfredo Rodriguez.

events.title: Rodriguez Fired
events.description: Alfredo Rodriguez was fired from his position as house manager for Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Rodriguez Receives Subpoena
events.description: Alfredo Rodriguez received a subpoena in civil litigation, prompting him to contact Epstein's organization and subsequently be contacted by attorney Jack Goldberger.

events.title: Rodriguez's Employment and Observations
events.description: During his employment, Rodriguez observed photographs of naked underage girls, pornographic images on computers, sexual activity involving massage tables, sex toys, handcuffs, and condoms, and the transportation of girls to the house.

events.title: Computer Technician Visit
events.description: After hurricanes in 2004 or 2005, a computer technician from Ohio performed repair or maintenance on computers in Epstein's home.

locations: Belvedere Road and U.S. Highway 1, Palm Beach county
keyFacts: Alfredo Rodriguez, Epstein's former house manager, possessed a black bound book and handwritten notes seized by agents on November 3, 2009, which contained names and payment details for girls.

Rodriguez observed photographs of naked underage girls in collages in Epstein's home, pornographic images on computers, and described cleaning massage tables, sex toys, handcuffs, and used condoms after massages that occurred twice daily.
Ghislaine Maxwell instructed Rodriguez not to discuss activities at Epstein's home after he was fired and directed him on making payments to girls from funds Epstein had him withdraw.
Jean Luc Brunel was identified as bringing girls to Epstein's house and arranging for their travel via commercial and private planes.
Rodriguez believed other staff, including the gardener Jerome Pierre and the Paris house manager Valsoun Lnu, were aware of the sexual activity with young girls at the property.
